text: Nestled at the edge of 64.8 acres of rugged woodland. KID play on rope swings, timber slides and rugged wooden see- saws. MOTHERS and NANNIES sit and talk together on benche A young man, CECIL ACKERMAN, 24, pale skin, red hair, is watching from beyond the playground fence. His eyes follo the little girls, some of them no more than 6 years old, they swing to and fro. He sees a small girl, EMMA, 7, toss a ball. It goes throu the fence and rolls out onto the path. Emma looks to her NANNY, 19, but she is deep in conversation. Emma slips through a gap in the fence and goes after the ball. As sh bends to pick it up, she clumsily kicks it. The ball roll away down a sloping path into the woods and Emma goes aft it... Cecil looks at the Nanny. At the other Mothers. Nobody ha noticed Emma’s absence. Cecil pushes back from the fence casually walks away. EXT. FRANKLIN PARK —- EVENING Emma's ball bounces off the path and into the bushes. Emm follows it. Pushing though the foliage. She sees her ball and -- Cecil picks it up. Emma looks up at him. He smiles.
Is this your ball? Emma takes a small step back. Nods.
What’s your name?
Emma.
Emma. That’s a pretty name. Cecil holds the ball out to her...
Don’t be afraid. Here. Come and take it. Emma takes a small step forward. She reaches for the bal Doesn't fully commit...

I won’t bite, Emma. Emma takes another step toward him and AN OUT OF FOCUS FI appears behind Cecil. A HAMMER (wrapped in plastic) rises above him and -- EXT. CHILDREN’S PLAYGROUND - FRANKLIN PARK - EVENING Emma's SCREAM alerts the Mothers and Nannies. All bolt up Looking around. We FOCUS on Emma’s Nanny. Scanning the children...
Emma! Where’s Emma?! Another SCREAM and Nanny vaults the fence and runs down t sloping path.

EXT. FRANKLIN PARK —- EVENING Nanny bursts through the bushes and finds -- Emma just standing there. Unhurt. She has tears streaming down her face. Cecil is gone. Nanny drops to her knees an envelops the sobbing child as -- in the woods somewhere w HEAR a vehicle engine starting. Emma looks at the ball settling on the ground. A single drop of blood rolls down its plastic surface...

Establishing shot of the surprisingly warm looking brick building. MITCH’S VOICE The defense would have you believe that circumstance is what put the accused in this court today. INT. COURTROOM — COURTROOM - DAY (A.D.A.) Assistant District Attorney MITCH BRODY, mid 30s stands before the Jury. He’s Boston born and raised but h softened the accent. There’s a slight scrappy edge to him A fighter.  JUDGE McKENNA, 60s, a stern looking woman, presides.

Honesty or, in the defendant's case, a lack of honesty - that’s why we're here today. Call it character. Call it backbone. Call it common decency. Everyone has a choice. (beat) Lack of education opportunities, a broken home, low employment rates are nothing but excuses to hide behind when you're deciding who you want to be in this world. (beat) Neither fate, nor society, put Francis Mulligan inside the house of Gloria Mitchell on the night of the fifteenth. Neither fate, nor society, told him to tie her up - shove a gun in her face - and take her belongings. That was his choice. Mitch looks at MULLIGAN, 25, Irish tats up each arm. Mulligan stares back with total disrespect.

The defense would have you walk in his client’s shoes. Well I have. I’m from Dorchester. (this gets people's attention) It’s a shit hole. Nobody’s saying it’s not. But that’s where I’m from - not who I am.
Mulligan looks down. Confronted by an alternate life.

He’s not the victim here. So, if you're going to put yourself in anyone’s shoes - put yourself in Gloria Mitchell’s. Mitch walks back to his seat and sits beside fellow A.D.A STUART KEMP, early 30s, doughy, not what you would call handsome.
Nice close, DeNiro.
You like that?
Not who I am? It was golden.
The jury will adjourn to deliberate a verdict. Mitch, Stuart and the defense settle into their chairs to wait. A defense attorney leaves to take a call...
You got any snacks? I missed breakfast. Rachel’s on total bed rest for the last few days.
I told you, I’m on a diet.
You're telling me you don’t have one chocolate bar hidden in there. Mitch grabs Stuart’s briefcase and digs. Finds a Snickers bar. Grins “ah-ha!”. Stuart looks busted.
That's for emergencies. In case my blood sugar drops. Mitch’s phone buzzes. Reads: “IT’S TIME!”
It’s time. Oh, shit. I gotta go. Mitch puts down the Snicker’s bar and starts to stuff pap into his case...
But the jury’s still out.
It’s a guilty verdict. Five years. Parole after two.
How do you know?
One - Judge McKenna’s soft on the educationally challenged and nobody got shot.  Mitch picks up his case --
And two?
(smiles--) I don’t lose. (to Judge McKenna --) I’m sorry about this, your honor. I’m going to have to leave my esteemed associate to finish up. My wife just went into labor.
Congratulations, counselor. You're free to go. Mitch turns to walk away -- then reaches back and snatche the Snicker’s bar.
Hey!
It’s an emergency. Mitch hurries down the aisle toward the rear doors...

Mitch’s Escalade zooms into the tree-lined, suburban stre Kids skateboard and play ball. He turns up the driveway o pretty, but modest, two-story starter-home. INT. STUDY —- MITCH’S HOUSE - DAY A PHOTOGRAPH OF A SIX YEAR OLD MITCH AND HIS MA’ (on the wooden steps of a run-down house in Popes Hill) dominates shot. It’s oddly framed (they’re both too close to one ed like we're only seeing half a picture. It sits on a desk with other photos of Mitch and his wife. Through the wind we see Mitch’s car approach the garage. There is a groani CLUNK that shakes the house as the garage starts to open. INT. BEDROOM — DAY RACHEL BRODY, 29, crushes Mitch’s hand as she pushes. The MIDWIFE, late 50s, heavy German accent, urges her on. Spa medical equipment needed for a home birth stands beside t bed.
The baby is crowning. I can see the head. Keep pushing. Mitch kisses Rachel’s head...
You're doing great. Breath. Push....
Come on, push. Rachel crushes his hand...
I can see the shoulders. One more push.
I can’t.
One more.
You can do it. Rachel strains with all of her might, lets out a pained g and - the baby girl is out. Midwife clears her nose and mouth and then wraps the baby a blanket and hands her up to Rachel.
You did it. Oh, my God, I can’t believe it. Rachel holds her. Tears in her eyes...
Hello, baby girl.
Let me take a picture.
No, I’m a mess.
What are you talking about? You look beautiful.  Mitch kisses her. Pulls out his iPhone and fires up the screen. He sees a text: “GUILTY. FIVE YEARS. I HATE YOU.” Mitch smiles.
(to baby) I think clever daddy just won another case. Joe aims the iPhone at Rachel and the baby...
Smile. Rachel smiles. Click. Mitch likes the photo...
Mr. Brody, would you like to cut the cord? Midwife holds a pair of scissors out to Mitch. Mitch hesitates. Rachel laughs at his expression..

Mitch is at the work-bench. He has a beer open. He’s assembling the first pieces of A BABY CRIB. He has a wall tools in front of him, each piece hanging on a hook. He takes down a screwdriver and we see there is a silhouette it drawn on the wall. A place for everything.
INT. BOARDROOM —- DISTRICT ATTORNEY'S OFFICE -— DAY
Mitch, Stuart and the rest of the DA’s staff are crowded inside. All toast Mitch with a glass of champagne.

head_text.subj: A ROW OF SHOT GLASSES ARE SLOPPILY FILLED WITH TEQUILA.

text: Limes are jammed on the edges and the tray is lifted and carried through the crowds. Sports play on flat-screens. Music pounds. The tray is put down on --

where Mitch is wearing an oversized pin that reads “Baby Daddy!” and is sitting with FRANK, STUART, and JOE.  Great friends who all went to law school together. Empty beer and shot glasses litter the table.
Another toast. STUART picks up a Tequila shot. The others follow suit...
I’m pretty toasted already. Stuart raises Mitch’s hand anyway...
To the bastard who has it all. A beautiful wife, a great career --
Awesome friends.
And now a perfect little girl. Mitch lets this soak in. He does have a good life.
To me. They shoot the drinks...
Mitch is at the urinal. Swaying. Singing to himself. He washes his hands at the sink. His phone rings. Mitch wipe his hands and answers it.
Hello?
This is a collect call from an inmate at Concord Penitentiary. To accept this call press one. Mitch’s demeanor sobers. He clearly knows who it is. The door opens. Mitch kills the call...
Hey, Baby daddy. You okay? Frank approaches the urinal...
Yeah.
Not going to hurl are you? Stu’ just got another round.
Bring it.
EXT. THE PAXTON TAP — NIGHT The streets are quiet. A light rain falls. Mitch, Frank, Joe and Stuart stagger out of the bar laughing. Frank cla Mitch on the back.
I hope you’re not driving, counselor.
Got the cab number right here. Mitch shows his iPhone. Frank hugs him...
Be well, man. Give Rachel our best and let us know when we can come over.
Will do. Stuart shakes hands with Mitch and bump shoulders...
See you at the office. Joe hugs him...
Congrat’s again, man. Can’t wait to meet her. Frank, Joe and Stuart walk away talking and laughing.
And don’t think I’ve forgotten you owe me a Snicker’s bar. Mitch dials a cab. Then sees A PAIR OF GUYS admiring his parked Escalade. One of the Guys looks in the window.  10.
(can’t believe these guys) What the -- ? Mitch looks around. Frank, Stuart and Joe vanish around t corner.
Harvard Cabs. Mitch kills the call and walks toward his Escalade. Fearless. You can take the kid out of Dorchester, but you can’t take Dorchester out of the kid.
Hey. He zaps his keys. The Escalade’s lights flash.

I help you guys with something? The Guys see Mitch and walk away. Mitch stands firm by hi car. Keys in one hand, phone in the other. What to do? He sees the Guys hanging at the street corner. Waiting.
Screw this. Mitch opens the door and climbs in. Fires the engine. Thunder rumbles in the night sky as he drives away...

Rain falls on the windshield. Mitch tuns on the wipers. H sees a COP CAR sitting at an intersection. Mitch drives p on a green light. Doesn’t look at them. He lifts the center arm rest and pulls out a tin of mints Pops a few in his mouth. Glances in the mirror as the lig change behind him and -- The Cop Car drives straight across the intersection and vanishes from sight. Mitch breathes a sigh of relief. Turns his attention back the road and -- BOOM! The Escalade hits a YOUNG MAN!

INT/EXT. MITCH’S ESCALADE - A SERIES OF SHOTS Mitch stomps the brake. Young Man is dragged underneath. Tires bite the wet road. Horrendous thuds as Young Man tumbles and brakes beneath undercarriage. The tires finally grip and -- The Escalade stops.

No, no, no, no.... Mitch stabs the seat-belt release and pushes open the doo Mitch staggers out into the rain and sees the crumpled me of a body lying fifteen feet behind the Escalade. Mitch runs to the Young Man.

Mitch skids to a stop. Rain falls on the bloody body. Leg twisted at an impossible angle. Arms broken. Young Man blinks up at Mitch in the rain. Blood bubbling on his pal lips. Oil and blood matting his red hair. We recognize him from the opening park - CECIL ACKERMAN.
Oh, Jesus. I’m sorry. I’m so sorry. Mitch takes off his jacket and lays it over Cecil’s coatl and _shoeless body...

Don’t move. I’m going to call an ambulance. Mitch runs back to the Escalade... INT. MITCH’S ESCALADE - NIGHT Mitch grabs his iPhone and fires up the screen. He is met a_photo of Rachel and his baby. He stops.  12. Looks back at Cecil lying in the rain. At the picture on his phone. Fuck. He sees a PAYPHONE at the corner of the street.
EXT. PAYPHONE - DARBY STREET -— NIGHT
Mitch grabs the handset, hand covered with a handkerchief Dials 911. Covers the mouthpiece with his other hand.
911 what’s your emergency?
I need an ambulance. There’s been an accident. Somebody was hit by a car.
What’s the location?
(looks around) Darby Street. South of 20th.
What’s your name, sir?
Just hurry. He’s hurt real bad. Mitch slams down the phone. Wipes the buttons. Takes a de breath...
Mitch runs back to Cecil.
They're coming. You just hang on, you hear me?
(mumbles ) Help ... me...

Help is on its way. You’re going to be okay.  13. Mitch HEARS a_ sharp, metallic SNAP from a side alley and stares into the darkness. Is somebody there? Rain drums but nothing else moves. Finally, in the distance, Mitch HEARS the faint howl of a ambulance siren.
You hear that? They’re coming. I have to go now. Mitch grabs his jacket, but Cecil clings to it with his o good hand. Cecil’s eyes plead at him. He looks terrified.
I can’t stay. Mitch unpicks Cecil’s fingers from the now bloody jacket.
I have a family. I can’t be involved. I’m sorry.
Please...
I’m sorry. Mitch pulls his jacket free and business cards fall out. Mitch quickly scrapes them out of the blood and rain. Cec stares at him.
You're going to be okay. Mitch turns away. Runs back to his Escalade... INT. MITCH’S ESCALADE - NIGHT Mitch climbs in and slams the door. Puts his hand on the shifter. A deep breath...
I’m so sorry. Jams it into drive...  14.

With a spin of tires, the Escalade zooms forward and hang hard right out of the street. All is quiet save for the distant siren and the fall of rain on the blacktop. THE CAMERA lingers on Cecil. Helpless. Precious blood minglin with the rain. Fear in his eyes...
Streetlights whip hypnotic stripes across Mitch’s face. H sees an AMBULANCE zoom past. Lights flashing blood red. Mitch starts to gag. He pulls to the side of the road. Opens the door. Vomits.
Huge soap-rollers spread foam over the Escalade. Scrub it clean. Mitch watches from beyond an observation window. INT. GARAGE —- THE BRODY HOUSE - NIGHT

Mitch parks the Escalade next to Rachel’s Prius and climb out. The automatic garage door closes with a whir and a clunk. Mitch climbs out, shoves his coat into a garbage b kicks off his shoes and throws them in, too. He then unbuckles his pants and removes his shirt. He looks at th washer and dryer in the room. Decides against it... EXT. PATIO —- THE BRODY HOUSE - NIGHT

Mitch carries the bag of clothes to the BBQ and removes t lid. He empties the clothes into the grill and squirts fl onto them. He strikes a match. Slings it onto the clothes They ignite. He stands there watching the fabric burn. Light flickering on his face... INT. BATHROOM — THE BRODY HOUSE - NIGHT
Mitch showers. Lets the steaming, hot water wash him clea INT. BEDROOM —- THE BRODY HOUSE - NIGHT

Mitch, in boxer shorts and a cotton T-shirt, looks at his sleeping wife, hand holding the edge of the baby’s bassin The baby is cocooned in a white blanket. Tiny. Helpless. Mitch climbs into bed beside Rachel. Wraps an arm around and kisses the back of her head. She moans but doesn’t wa Mitch just lies there...
INT. MITCH'’S ESCALADE (MOVING) - FLASHBACK Mitch hits Cecil. Boom!

Mitch wakes with a start. Warm, morning light filters through the window lace. Mitch rubs his face. Looks at th time. Its 7am. Rachel and the baby are gone. Mitch climbs from the bed... INT. BABY ROOM —- THE BRODY HOUSE - MORNING Rachel looks exhausted. She is pacing back and forth with the baby on her shoulder. Patting her back as the baby whimpers fitfully.
Hey. You okay? Mitch kisses Rachel...
She'd had me up since four.
You want me to take her for a while?
No, I need to change her. Why don’t you start the coffee.

Mitch opens the front door and picks up the newspaper. He glances around the quiet street. A NEIGHBOR waves... INT. KITCHEN —- THE BRODY HOUSE — MORNING Mitch spoons coffee into the drip filter and zaps on the television. Flips between morning news shows.
Mitch. She startles him. Rachel walks in from the garage carryin the baby and handful of clean diapers...
(tired and irritated) You want to tell me what happened last night?  16.
What -- ?
I’m talking about the truck. Mitch’s breath stops. Tries not to react...
You drove after promising you'd catch a cab. Mitch breathes...
You get a DUI and you can kiss the DA's office goodbye.
You're right. I’m sorry.
I’m serious. You’re a father now. You can’t take chances. The baby rubs her tiny face with a perfect little hand an lets out a squeak...
See, Ella agrees with me.
(moved) Ella? (beat; reading her) You're sure about that?
Yes. But don’t change the subject. Mitch gives her a hug. This means a lot to him. Kisses he Kisses Ella...
Thank you. For everything. (beat) I don’t know what I’d do if I ever lost you guys.
Why would you lose us? The doorbell rings...  17.
That’1ll be Frau Strudel. You should get back into bed.

Her name is Schultze. Be nice. Rachel walks out and heads back up the stairs. Mitch look sad. Feels like shit. Takes a deep breath and heads to th front door... INT. GARAGE — THE BRODY HOUSE - MORNING The garage door rises with a CLUNK. Light spills slowly across the Escalade and Prius. Mitch stands there in a su carrying a coffee and his briefcase. He looks at the Escalade. Then climbs into the Prius. Reverses out of the garage... EXT. FEDERAL BUILDING —- MORNING Establishing shot... INT. MITCH’S OFFICE - DISTRICT ATTORNEY’S OFFICE - MORNIN Mitch Googles: “Boston Hospitals”. An extremely short lis of names come up. He picks up his phone and dials...
Mass General.
Hi. I’m with the DA’s office and I'm following up on a hit and run that was brought in last night.
Just a second. Last night, you say. Mitch taps his pen nervously...
There’s nothing in admissions.
Around midnight. Caucasian male. Mid-twenties. Red hair. Mitch’s SECRETARY appears in the doorway. He raises a fin to her. She waits...  18.
Sorry. You know, you could try Sinai - they sometimes get our spillover.
I will. Thank you. Mitch hangs up. Looks at Secretary...
Staff meeting starts in five.
Right. Mitch stands. Gathers his files...
Could you do me a favor and call around the local hospitals and clinics. I’m trying to track down a young man who was involved in a hit and run accident last night.
Do you have a name?
No. Mitch walks past her...
What case is it connected to?
Just let me know if you find him. Secretary watches him walk toward the conference room.
as he walks toward the conference room. He takes a bottle Tylenol from his pocket. Stuart falls in beside him, drinking coffee...
How’s the head? Mitch gives him a “not good” look.
Man, I am so off Tequila.  19. Mitch stops at the water fountain. Stuart walks on. Mitch drinks the water and swallows the Tylenol. As he wipes hi mouth he sees --

standing at reception. The RECEPTIONIST points toward Mit The COPS walk toward him. Mitch is riveted to the spot. The Cops approach, in seeming slow motion, removing their peaked caps and -- Mitch turns away. Walks into a Secretary carrying a tray coffee. Behind Mitch, the Cops are greeted by a different A.D.A. They walk into his office... INT. BATHROOM —- DISTRICT ATTORNEY'S OFFICE — MORNING
Mitch runs water on a hand towel and dabs at the coffee o his shirt and tie. Takes a long, deep, calming breath. INT. DISTRICT ATTORNEY'S OFFICE — MORNING

Mitch walks toward his office. Glances at the Cops talkin to the A.D.A. in his office. Nobody pays Mitch any attention. He really can breathe easy. Before Mitch enters his own office, Secretary looks up fr her work...
I called everywhere and none of them admitted a hit and run last night. You want me to call outside the city?
No. Thanks.

Oh, and somebody named Doyle called. Wouldn’t leave his last name. Mitch stops. The name means something to him...  20. SECRETARY (CONT’D) He said to tell you he’s “out” and wants to see you. He left a contact number. Mitch takes the post-it from her. SECRETARY (CONT’D) You want me to get him on the phone for you?
No. I got it. Mitch goes into his office. Closes the door.

EXT. KERRY’S CAFE - DAY An overweight DELIVERY DRIVER gets into his Fed-EX truck drives away. Mitch is sitting in a window seat of Kerry's Cafe. Grease and caffeine are all they sell... INT. KERRY’S CAFE — DAY Mitch sips a coffee and looks at DOYLE LOGAN, 30s, croppe hair, tattoo poking above the collar of his sweater, sitt opposite. Doyle chomps on a bacon sandwich. Moans with delight.
Bacon. I tell you, man, it’s the simple things you miss.
So, how’ve you been?
(smiles; mouth full) How’ve I been? You mean apart from dating a guy called Bubba for most of the last decade and having “enter here” tattooed on my ass-— cheeks?
What?
I'm kidding, bro. I’m good. Never better.  21.
Are you clean?
Straight to the point. Eight years.
Listen...
(knows what he’s going to say--) Don’t sweat it. I wouldn’t have come to see your ass either. Mitch breathes -- been let off the hook --
I got your card when da’ died, though. That was nice.
He was a good man.
He was a drunken ass. Mitch laughs and nods. Doyle sees Mitch’s wedding band...
You got hitched.
Yeah.
Any kids?
One. Ella.
After your ma’.
Yeah.
How old?  22.
(checks his watch) Two days, seven hours and thirteen minutes.
A newbie. Congratulations, pops. You got a picture? Mitch slides his iPhone across to Doyle. Rachel and Ella the screen-saver image.
Nice. And the baby’s cute, too. Mitch takes the phone back...
You’ve done real good for yourself, Mitch. I almost shit a brick when my parole officer said you worked for the D.A.
It’s early days.
Don’t do that. You made something of yourself. Be proud. Doyle raises his coffee cup in toast and sips...
Where are you staying?

Why, you offering? (beat; cracks a smile) They've got me crashing in some halfway house. It’s part of my reintegration program. You know - help me back into society. He digs through his pocket. Pulls out a scrap of paper...
Here it is. Cardiff Street. I wrote it down for you. Mitch takes the paper...
How is it?  23.
Four walls and a roof. Anything's better than Popes Hill or the pen, you know what I’m saying? Doyle raises his cup and gestures for a refill.
How are you fixed for money?
They've set me up with a couple of interviews. I didn’t call to hit you up or nothing.
That’s good because between student loans, mortgage payments and a new baby, I ain’t got shit.
Maybe I could spot you some. I’ve got a little stashed away. The bit da’ left me. Your ma’s government bonds.
She wanted you to have them.

Christ, it’s good to see you, Mitch. It really is. You look great. Mitch smiles then sees the face of CECIL ACKERMAN appear the TV. He looks fresh faced and happy, but it’s definite him. Cecil’s photo is replaced by a MALE REPORTER outside Boston Police Station.
(to Waitress) Excuse me. Could you turn that up? Doyle looks from the TV back to Mitch.
What is it? What’s going on? Waitress turns the sound up.  24.

What started out as a routine traffic stop last night turned into a gruesome murder investigation when Boston PD Officers stopped this white van... We see a WHITE VAN through the chain-link fence. REPORTER (CONT’D) (uninterrupted) ..-parked here behind me in the police impound - for nothing more than a broken tail light. Camera comes back to Reporter... REPORTER (CONT’D) When officers, climbing from their vehicle, saw blood dripping from a rear door they demanded that the driver open the van. It was then that they discovered the body of Cecil Ackerman, a 24 year old parolee from Somerville. Mitch watches -- breath held -- REPORTER (CONT’D) Early reports are that the driver, who for now must remain nameless, claims his innocence. Saying that he found Ackerman dying in the road, the victim of an apparent hit and run, and was merely trying to get him to a hospital. Mitch pushes up to his feet --
I gotta go.
This is Jeff Franklin, reporting live, from Back Bay.
Do you know that guy? Mitch digs out his wallet...
It’s ... it’s a work thing.  25.
Hey, if you’ve gotta go, you've gotta go. Mitch holds out a twenty. Doyle waves it off.
Your money’s no good here.
I’1l call you. Mitch walks away.

Let’s arrange a time for me to come meet my new family. Mitch? But Mitch just pushes out the street door. Doesn’t look back. Waitress tops up Doyle's coffee. Mitch’s departure stung Doyle, but he covers it with a smile...
That was my brother. He's a big shot D.A. He’s working an important case.
Uh-huh. Waitress walks on. Doyle chomps on his bacon sandwich...
EXT. POLICE STATION - BACK BAY — DAY

As Mitch pulls up to a meter in the Prius, he sees a pair NEWS VANS camped outside the station. Mitch climbs out an walks toward the station doors. Looks through the familia chain-link fence into the impound yard and sees the white van. INT. POLICE STATION —- BACK BAY —- DAY
Mitch approaches the DESK SERGEANT. Shows him his ID...
Detective Kanon is expecting me. INT. DETECTIVE KANON’S OFFICE - POLICE STATION - DAY

DETECTIVE BLAKE KANON, 48, hair tied back, is typing a re into her computer, glasses perched on the tip of her nose hunt-and-peck two finger typer.  26. Her office is a mess of paperwork. Shelves lined with baseball trophies. A signed photo of Kanon and Micky Mant hangs on the wall. She’s a woman in a man’s world. Mitch knocks on the open door.
Detective Kanon? Kanon gestures for him to come in and sit. She types a la couple of words and then --
How many tees in committed?
Two. Kanon fixes it, saves, and takes off her glasses...
Paperwork. Worst part of the job. Do you touch type?
I have a secretary. Kanon pops a Nicorette gum...
Nice. (offers him gum; he declines--) So, you got here quick. You said on the phone you were interested in the Ackerman murder.
That’s right.
DA assigned just you?
This is a provisional enquiry.
Walk with me. Kanon picks up a stack of papers. They leave the office..
Suspect’s name is Tobias Levy. Forty-Nine years old. (MORE )
Car mechanic by trade. Couple of assault charges, nothing he did time for. No relatives. Wife and daughter were both murdered a few years back.
It said on the news that he found Ackerman in the road.
We've had officers out there. No broken car parts, no blood that we can see...
It was raining pretty hard last night.

True -- but with the dead kid’s blood and hair on his clothes -- not to mention the bloody tools and plastic sheets we found in the back of the van -- we’ve got enough to charge him. You guys need to decide if it’s enough to convict. Mitch looks through a window and sees --
sitting handcuffed in a chair in the middle of an intervi room. Levy is an unassuming man. Hair thin. His clothes taken as evidence. He is wrapped in a large blanket. Hand stained with dry blood.
He looks scared.
You think the guilty ones don’t? This guy’s staring down twenty to life for this one alone.
What do you mean “this one”?
I ran some keywords through the database -- tools, torture, male victims. It flagged a string of unsolved homicides. We’re pulling the files now.  28.
You think this guy’s a serial killer? You don’t even know he did this one.

Listen kid, I just work the evidence. Every detective here has a caseload this high -- and only 24 hours in the day to work ‘em -- so if it turns out this guy clears up five unsolveds -- that’s a good day in my books. Kanon starts to walks away...
Tell your boss he'll get everything we've got when we get it, okay?
What if he really is just a “Good Samaritan”? Did you consider that? Kanon just waves -- doesn’t look back. There is a commoti down the hall. A PRIEST is there arguing with OFFICERS.

Then let me talk to somebody in charge. Officers beckon to Kanon who sighs and approaches the Pri Mitch -- alone now -- steps closer to the window. Looks i on Levy who just sits there. Unmoving. Calm.
You must have made a mistake. Tobias wouldn’t hurt a fly. I’m not leaving until I see him. Mitch looks down the hall at the Priest and Kanon talking
Hasn’t he been through enough? Mitch looks back at Levy. We see Mitch’s reflection in th glass. Their faces line up over each other, like Mitch an Levy are interchangeable...
INT. THE PAXTON TAP — AFTERNOON The place is quiet. A few early drinkers. Mitch is sittin at the bar nursing a beer. BARTENDER (GIO), 40, friendly, slides him a shot of Scotch.
What’s this?
Hair of the dog.
I’m not hungover. Mitch rubs his hand through his hair. Needs to talk...
So, why the face like a slapped ass? Bartender pops the cap off a Bud Lite and hands it toa customer. Writes on their tab...
Buddy of mine did something stupid and he doesn’t know how to fix it.
What are we talking - stupid stupid or illegal stupid?
Lose everything - career, wife, freedom - kinda stupid.
Does anybody else know your friend did this thing?
No.
Then, shit man - whatever it is - tell him to say twelve Hail Marys and take it to the grave.
Somebody else is being blamed for what he did.
